bill_title: provide certain provisions regarding the regulation of tattooing.

bill_versions.bill_text: An Act to provide certain provisions regarding the regulation of tattooing. Be it enacted by the Legislature of the State of South Dakota: Section 1. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-1. Definitions. Terms used in this chapter mean: (1) "Department," the Department of Health; (2) "Guest tattoo artist," a person who is licensed, registered, or certified to practice tattooing in a jurisdiction outside of this state who is registered with the department to practice tattooing in this state; (3) "Patron," a person who receives a tattoo or saline tattoo removal; (4) "Secretary," the secretary of the Department of Health; (5) "Tattoo," a mark or design made on or under the skin of a human being by a process of piercing and ingraining a pigment, dye, or ink in the skin; (6) "Tattoo artist," a person engaged in the practice of tattooing, applying permanent body make-up, or microblading; (7) "Tattoo establishment," the building or structure where tattooing is practiced; (8) "Tattoo procedure," the service performed or the procedure utilized for tattooing. Section 2. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-2. Exclusions from chapter. (1) This chapter does not apply to a person licensed to practice medicine or dentistry under chapter 36-4 or chapter 36-6A who performs tattooing exclusively for medical or dental purposes. (2) This chapter applies only to the tattooing of human beings and does not apply to the tattooing of any animal. Section 3. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-3. Tattoo establishment--Licensure. An applicant seeking to create a tattooing establishment in this state shall obtain an annual license from the department. An applicant shall apply to the department in the format promulgated by the department, pursuant to chapter 1-26. An application shall include: (1) The registered business name, including any fictitious names under which the tattoo establishment conducts business in the state; (2) The street address and telephone number of the tattoo establishment; (3) The name, mailing address, and telephone number of the tattoo establishment's manager; (4) The name and address of the tattoo establishment's registered agent for service of process in the state; and (5) The tax identification number the establishment shall collect and report sales tax to the Department of Revenue. The department shall issue the license if the applicant submits a completed application, pays the applicable fee, and has passed an inspection pursuant to this chapter and the rules promulgated by the department. A temporary tattoo establishment shall meet the same requirements as a permanent tattoo establishment. A license under this section is nontransferable except in the case of a change in ownership. Section 4. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-4. Tattoo Establishment--Requirements. A tattoo establishment shall: (1) Display an active license for the establishment in a manner that is easily visible to the public at all times while tattooing is performed at the establishment; (2) Ensure that each tattoo artist and guest tattoo artist, while practicing tattooing at the establishment, meets all applicable requirements of this chapter; (3) Maintain sanitary conditions of the establishment at all times; (4) Comply with all state and local health codes and ordinances; (5) Allow the department to inspect the establishment; (6) Comply with this chapter and rules promulgated by the department and (7) Files sales tax returns to the Department of Revenue on a monthly basis. Section 5. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-5. Fees--Promulgation of rules. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, establishing the: (1) Fee, not to exceed six hundred dollars, for the licensure and renewal of a tattoo establishment; (2) Fee, not to exceed two hundred dollars, for licensure of a temporary establishment; (3) Fee, not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars, for the licensure and renewal of a tattoo artist; (4) Fee, not to exceed two hundred dollars, for licensure and renewal of a guest tattoo artist; (5) Fee, not to exceed two hundred dollars, for reactivation of an inactive tattoo establishment license or tattoo artist license. A license becomes inactive if it is not renewed before the expiration of the current license; and (6) Fee, not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars, for the inspection of an establishment under this chapter. All fees collected under this chapter shall be deposited in the state general fund. No license under this section is transferable except if a tattoo establishment is only changing ownership. Section 6. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-6. Tattoo procedure--Prohibitions--Violation as misdemeanor. A person may not: (1) Perform a tattoo procedure if the person performing the procedure is under eighteen years of age; (2) Perform a tattoo procedure on another person who is under the influence of drugs or alcohol; (3) Perform a tattoo procedure on a person who is under eighteen years of age, unless the parent or guardian is present and written consent has been given by the minor patron's parent or guardian in accordance with § 34-54-7. However, the provisions of this subdivision do not apply to a person who has been emancipated by marriage; (4) Tattoo any site in which the skin surface exhibits any evidence of unhealthy conditions; (5) Provide false information to a tattoo artist or establishment concerning a patron's identification, age, or health; (6) Perform a tattoo procedure without a valid tattoo artist license; (7) Perform a tattoo procedure at a location without a valid tattoo establishment license; (8) Provide false information on an application for licensure or registration; (9) Commit fraud, deceit, negligence, or misconduct in the practice of tattooing or the operation of a tattoo establishment or temporary establishment; (10) Aid, procure, or assist a person to practice tattooing unlawfully or unlawfully operate a tattoo establishment; or (11) Fail to keep the written notarized consent of the parent or guardian of a minor child who is tattooed at a tattoo establishment or knowingly making false entries in a parent's or guardian's written notarized consent. A violation of this section is a Class 2 misdemeanor. A second violation of the same offense under this section is a Class 1 misdemeanor. Section 7. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-7. Minor--Consent by parent or guardian--Signed statement. For a person under the age of eighteen, a parent or guardian who desires to give consent to an establishment for performance of a tattoo procedure on the person under the age of eighteen shall: (1) Appear in person at the establishment at the time the procedure is performed; (2) Produce proof of age of the attesting person; and (3) Sign a form provided by the establishment that: (a) States the minor’s gender and age in years; (b) Explains the manner in which the procedure will be performed and the methods for proper care of the affected body area following performance of the procedure; and (c) Requires signing of a statement with the exact wording as follows: "I, the undersigned, certify that I am the parent or guardian of the named minor and further give consent to the tattoo procedure(s) as explained. I acknowledge that I am fully aware that to falsify my legal standing as to being the minor's parent or guardian constitutes a Class 2 misdemeanor. A Class 2 misdemeanor means imprisonment for not greater than thirty days or a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars or both (SDCL 22-6-2)." Section 8. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-8. Tattoo establishment--Required records--Contents--Duration. A tattoo establishment shall keep a record of each patron that includes name, address, age, consent form with medical inquiry, and the location and description of each tattoo. This record shall be available for inspection and kept for at least two years. For minors who receive a tattoo as allowed under § 34-54-7, the establishment shall forward to the department within thirty business days following performance of the tattoo procedure, and the department shall retain such paperwork for two years. This paperwork shall include: (1) A copy of the proof of age of the attesting person; and (2) The signed document that the person is the minor's parent or guardian that provides permission to perform a tattoo procedure on a minor and that stipulates that the attesting person understands the consequences for falsifying their legal standing as to being the parent or guardian. The department may promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, on the necessary paperwork that shall be submitted to the department under this section. Section 9. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-9. Tattooing--Licensure--Requirements--Promulgation of rules. On and after January 1, 2021, no person may perform a tattooing procedure without being licensed as a tattoo artist. A person seeking licensure as a tattoo artist shall apply to the department. An application shall include the name and residence address of the applicant and the name and street address of each tattoo establishment at which the applicant intends to practice tattooing in this state. The department shall issue the license if the applicant: (1) Submits a completed application (2) Pays all applicable fees; (3) Undergoes a training program on sterilization procedures and bloodborne pathogens, approved or promulgated by the department pursuant to chapter 1-26; (4) Submits proof that the applicant has taken and passed an examination concerning bloodborne pathogens, sterilization techniques, the provisions of this chapter, and any rules promulgated by the department concerning tattooing; and (5) Has not been registered as a sex offender under § 22-24B-2 or in another state. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, regarding acceptable forms of proof, application materials, application procedures, and any exam or examination materials under this section. Section 10. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-10. Out-of-state tattoo artists--Licensure--Promulgation of rules. In order to obtain a license, an out-of-state tattoo artist shall show proof of at least two-years of experience as a tattoo artist in another state. For purposes of this section, proof of business or experience may be: (1) A copy of a business license; (2) Another state's artist's license; or (3) Tax records, or other similar city, county, state, or federal documents that show the prospective applicant as having been in business or operation. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, regarding the forms of documentation that may be submitted as evidence or proof under this section. Section 11. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-11. Inspections--Promulgation of rules. The secretary shall conduct at least one inspection of a tattoo establishment prior to issuing a license to perform tattoo procedures. The secretary shall conduct an annual inspection before renewing a license to operate a tattoo establishment. The secretary may inspect a tattoo establishment at any time the secretary deems necessary and shall be given access to the premises and to all records deemed relevant by the secretary for the inspection. Inspection results for tattoo establishments shall be recorded on standard department forms that summarize the requirements of the law and rules and regulations. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, to establish the standards for inspections of establishments and forms for recording compliance with these standards. Section 12. That a NEW SECTION be added: 34-54-12. Failure of inspection--Suspension or revocation of license. If an establishment fails an inspection under § 34-54-11, the secretary shall give the establishment thirty days to correct any violations to come into compliance. If the secretary determines the establishment failed to correct the violations after a re-inspection, the secretary shall initiate proceedings to suspend the establishment's license until the violation is corrected, pursuant to a hearing under § 1-26-29. If the secretary determines that the establishment failed to correct the violation within ninety days of suspension, the secretary shall revoke the establishment's license. Section 13. That § 9-34-17 be AMENDED: 9-34-17. Tattooing, saline tattoo removal, and body piercing. Any municipality may regulate the practice of tattooing, saline tattoo removal, and body piercing by licensing practitioners of tattooing, saline tattoo removal, or body piercing; inspecting tattoo, saline tattoo removal, and body piercing establishments; and establishing standards for sanitation that are at least as stringent as those adopted in chapter 34-54 or by the Department of Health under § 34-1-17. Terms used in this section mean: (1) "Tattooing," to make marks or designs into the skin by puncturing it and inserting indelible colors. The term includes, permanent make-up, microblading, and similar techniques to microblading used to partially or fully simulate natural hair; (2) "Saline tattoo removal," inserting a saline solution in skin to lighten or remove an existing tattoo. The term does not include the use of other acids or of lasers as described in § 36-4-8.2; (3) "Body piercing," to place a permanent or temporary foreign object in a person's body for a decorative or other nonmedical purpose by a person not directly under the supervision of a licensed physician as defined by § 36-4-11. The department shall certify any municipality that wishes to operate its own tattoo establishment licensing program and inspection program for tattoo establishments in compliance with this section. Section 14. That § 34-1-17 be AMENDED: 34-1-17. Promulgation of rules--Orders, rules, and licensing--Matters covered. The Department of Health may adopt and enforce, subject to chapter 1-26, orders and rules necessary to preserve and protect the public health and may regulate, by requiring licenses or other appropriate means, control, and, in proper cases, prohibit and suppress any of the following matters: (1) The manufacture into articles of commerce, other than food, of diseased, tainted, or decayed animal or vegetable matter; (2) The location of cemeteries and the removal and burial of the dead; (3) The management of lying-in houses and boarding places for infants, and the treatment of infants therein; (4) The construction and equipment, in respect to sanitary conditions, of schools, hospitals, prisons, and other public institutions; (5) The treatment in hospitals and elsewhere of persons suffering from any communicable disease, the disinfection and quarantine of persons and places in case of disease, and the reporting of sickness and deaths from disease; (6) The distribution of biological products to be used for the prevention and treatment of communicable diseases; (7) The diagnosis, control, and treatment of tuberculosis; and (8) The minimum sanitation requirements for tattooing, saline tattoo removal, and body piercing as defined in § 9-34-17, including premises, licensure, equipment, methods of operation, and freedom from communicable disease. Section 15. This bill shall go into effect on January 1, 2021.
